subject: Re: [junit] How to test webservices using JUnit?
msgSnippet: Hi, If you re using IBM RAD or RSA, there is an option to add Test on your WebService and it will do it for you and it s pretty cool because you don t need to
messageBody:
Hi,

If you're using IBM RAD or RSA, there is an option to add Test on your WebService and it will do it for you and it's pretty cool because you don't need to waste time to figure it out on how to do it.

Thanks,




________________________________
From: Scott Glaser <sglaser@...>
To: "junit@yahoogroups.com" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, August 10, 2009 1:57:35 PM
Subject: RE: [junit] How to test webservices using JUnit?


Another alternative is to use Apache Axis, use WSDL2Java to create client stubs bindings then create JUnit tests using the client stubs to access your web services.
http://ws.apache org/axis2/

Scott

From: junit@yahoogroups. com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups. com] On Behalf Of R Donovan
Sent: Monday, August 10, 2009 1:41 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups. com
Subject: Re: [junit] How to test webservices using JUnit?

Hi regarding testing web services with JUnit there are a number of
approaches. A common one is to test the internal business logic using Junit
and then test the actual services using something that supports
concurrency like Jmeter.

Alternatively I have also tested the actual service with Junit using my own
service client (modified apache httpclient) also apparently XFire has a
http client that can be used to act a client.

You may find xmlUnit also very handy for validating your service responses.

Richard
(rdonovan2004 at gmail.com)

On Sat, Aug 8, 2009 at 3:42 AM, B. Sai Prasad, M.Phil, SCJP, MCP, MCTS,
SSGB, PMP, PMI-SP <sai.prasad.b@ gmail.com<mailto:sai. prasad.b% 40gmail.com> > wrote:

>
>
> Hi -
>

> some of them are exposed as webservices. I would like to test these
> webservices using JUnit or its supporting frameworks.
>
> Please suggest
> Thanks in advance
> Sai
